Title: Linking forum posts - neuralnets-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Lecture 5 - Trying to get my head around convolutional nets
Input.posts:
So , what I have understood is this If we have, for instance, 4x4 image, we divide it into 4 2x2 patches, each patch provides n inputs to neuron, so we have 4 neurons (detectors) on a layer above inputs. For each of those 4 neurons-detectors we apply a constraint during training - weights of their input connections must look the same, so we update weights accordingly (using the sum of gradients). Now, we connect patches to many sets of 4 2x2 neurons (maps) and magically it gives us good results. Is that close?
Upvotes:
4
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Close, what you said is true when there is a stride of 2 (a stride describes how much to move the filters for the next hidden unit). With a stride of 1 you can actually get 9 hidden units for that map, and a lot of the filters will overlap each other on the image. The second ingredient that makes the 'magic' work is pooling. This is what gives the network invariance to small translations in the data. We need to decide which neurons to pool, and it's usually within the same map. For example, if we had the following spatial arrangement of hidden units for a single map: $$h_1$$ $$h_2$$ $$h_3$$ $$h_4$$ $$h_5$$ $$h_6$$ $$h_7$$ $$h_8$$ $$h_9$$ Then we might choose to pool $$h_1,h_2,h_4,h_5$$ and $$h_2,h_3,h_5,h_6$$ etc. (notice how they can overlap).
Instructor's post : Close, what you said is true when there is a stride of 2 (a stride describes how much to move the filters for the next hidden unit). With a stride of 1 you can actually get 9 hidden units for that map, and a lot of the filters will overlap each other on the image. The second ingredient that makes the 'magic' work is pooling. This is what gives the network invariance to small translations in the data. We need to decide which neurons to pool, and it's usually within the same map. For example, if we had the following spatial arrangement of hidden units for a single map: $$h_1$$ $$h_2$$ $$h_3$$ $$h_4$$ $$h_5$$ $$h_6$$ $$h_7$$ $$h_8$$ $$h_9$$ Then we might choose to pool $$h_1,h_2,h_4,h_5$$ and $$h_2,h_3,h_5,h_6$$ etc. (notice how they can overlap).
Upvotes:
4

Title: Linking forum posts - neuralnets-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Cross entropy cost function when target is 0
Input.posts:
I'm not understanding the use of the softmax cost function. If a target is expected to be 0, then the cross entropy cost function doesn't seem to care what the output 'y' is. Why is this? I'm assuming during training, I would want the cost function to increase if my target is 0 and my output y is 1, thereby allowing the network to adjust the weights so that the output y is 0 to match target 0. Thanks.
Upvotes:
2
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Walter, I'm afraid I don't fully understand the question.. If you look at the derivatives of the cross-entropy error it does indeed increase/decrease the weights to make the prediction better match the target.
Instructor's post : Hi Walter, I'm afraid I don't fully understand the question.. If you look at the derivatives of the cross-entropy error it does indeed increase/decrease the weights to make the prediction better match the target.
Upvotes:
0

Was this in the lectures? I assumed that linear threshhold was just taking a linear function and thresholding it, eg f(x) = 1 if (w*x > b) , 0 otherwise But based on Quiz 2 I assume that is a binary threshold and linear threshold is something else (maybe floor(w*x) ?) What is linear threshold? (Google gives no answer for this)
Upvotes:
0
Hi. Yes, it is on the lectures under the name 'Rectified Linear Neurons' z = b + Sum( x(i) * w(i) for every i ) ) y = z if z > 0. 0 otherwise.
